issues.description: Constructor signature mismatch for SealSaloon: The problem statement (UML and text) requires a constructor SealSaloon(String) that takes a saloon name, but both the provided example usage in the template/Main and the solution implement and use a no-argument constructor SealSaloon(). This conflict will confuse students about which constructor to implement and whether a name field is required (and whether a getter for it is expected).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the constructor requirement consistent across artifacts. Either (A) update the template and solution to provide a constructor public SealSaloon(String name) (store the name in a private final field and add a getter) and update Main to call new SealSaloon("name"), or (B) change the problem statement to specify a no-argument constructor (and remove the instruction that a saloon name must be passed). Option A is recommended because it matches the current problem text (UML + description) and the requirement to add getters for private fields.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and text) specifies a SealSaloon constructor that takes a String parameter (SealSaloon(String)) for identification, but the provided solution implements only a no-argument constructor (SealSaloon()). This creates an API/identifier mismatch: students reading the problem expect to implement or call SealSaloon(String) while the solution and example Main use/contain a no-arg constructor. The mismatch can confuse students about the required constructor signature and how to instantiate the class.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the API between specification and code. Either update the solution to provide the constructor SealSaloon(String name) (for example: public SealSaloon(String name) { this.orders = new Meal[]{}; /* optionally store name */ }) or update the problem statement/UML to document that a no-argument constructor is intended. If backward compatibility is desired, add an overloaded constructor (both SealSaloon() and SealSaloon(String)) so students and example code work with either form.
